para.paratext: O.C.G.A. § 24-8-806, “Attacking and supporting credibility of a declarant,” provides as follows:

When a hearsay statement has been admitted in evidence, the credibility of the declarant may be attacked and, if attacked, may be supported by any evidence which would be admissible for those purposes if the declarant had testified as a witness. Evidence of a statement or conduct by the declarant at any time, inconsistent with the declarant's hearsay statement, shall not be subject to any requirement that the declarant may have been afforded an opportunity to deny or explain. If the party against whom a hearsay statement has been admitted calls the declarant as a witness, the party shall be entitled to examine the declarant on the statement as if under cross-examination.

Georgia courts have already expressly adopted the view expressed in Fed. R. Evid. 806, and now the language of O.C.G.A. § 24-8-806 mirrors the federal rule as well. For example, when a dying declaration is admitted against a criminal defendant, he is permitted to show the general bad character of the declarant.[1]

Difficulty arises when the attack is made by showing other statements contradictory to the declaration. O.C.G.A. §§ 24-4-405 and 24-6-608 require a foundation for this method of impeachment. The courts have so strictly construed this foundational requirement that depositional testimony of a witness cannot be used because he cannot be asked about the contradictory statement.[2] If no foundation can be established because a declarant is unavailable, then the contradictory declaration cannot be used for impeachment.[3]

However, this requirement had been relaxed in a few areas. Where a dying declaration is introduced either by or against a criminal defendant, a contradictory statement by the declarant may be shown without laying a foundation.[4]

In a probate case, Mobley v. Lyon,[5] the attesting witnesses were deceased and evidence was introduced as to their signatures. The court held that it was proper to show a statement by one of the witnesses that the testatrix had not made a will.

In a case of first impression, the Georgia Court of Appeals clarified the rule regarding the foundational requirement for a statement by a now unavailable witness in Brantley v. State.[6] That case involved impeachment of a declarant who had not testified, but whose hearsay declaration had been admitted as res gestae. The court followed Fed. R. Evid. 806 and held that the declarant was subject to impeachment.[7]

Subsequently, the Georgia Court of Appeals expanded this rationale by holding that a party must be given the opportunity to impeach the credibility of a declarant whose statement is admitted under the medical diagnosis or treatment exception to the hearsay rule.[8] A party may also impeach the credibility of an accountant that prepared a chart of business finances to be used at trial, even though the witness testified that she had aided in creating the chart.[9]

The courts have held that it is not ineffective assistance of counsel where defense attorney does not object to hearsay testimony of declarants where defense attorney had a reasonable trial strategy for doing so, including the fact that the declarants may be called to testify.[10]
